newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft to pay patent fee to Apple.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft to pay patent fee to Apple.

text.p: BOSTON, Aug 6, Reuter - Apple Computer Inc chief financial officer Fred Anderson said that Microsoft Corp will pay Apple a non-disclosed sum, in addition to its previously-announced $150 million investment, as part of its sweeping patent cross-licensing agreement with Apple.

Anderson said that under terms of the agreement he could not be more specific about the amount, which is in addition to the $150 million Microsoft will spend to purchase preferred non-voting Apple shares.
Anderson said Apple will not recognize the entire payment in one quarter, but will spread out the cash payment as income over a few years.

"The payment is one way," Anderson told reporters at a press conference concerning its deal with Microsoft. "We have a license to their patent portfolio and they have a license to our patent portfolio," he said.
Anderson also said Apple hopes to add a few more board members, because the company has slots for an additional three.
With the resignations of all but two Apple board members earlier Wednesday and the addition of four new board members, Apple now has six board members.

"The changes bring us to six," Anderson said. "I think it would be very good if we had someone from education on the board. One could argue that you could also have someone from a consumer marketing background. We will probably add some new board members." The new board members will be compensated in stock.
Anderson said the board members who resigned did so because they saw it in the best interest of the company.
Anderson said Apple hopes the new board members, including well-known industry executives, will help Apple draw the interest of a "world-class CEO."

"Some of these executives have been involved in major corporate turnarounds," Anderson said. Jerry York, for example, was hand picked by CEO Louis Gerstner at International Business Machines Corp in 1993 to help him turn around the money-losing computer giant, which included a massive write-off and hefty layoffs. Anderson added though, that Apple does not have any plans for further layoffs at this time.
Anderson said that with new board members in place, Apple hopes to move full speed ahead in its search for a CEO to succeed Gil Amelio, who was ousted by the board last month.

"John Thompson (the executive at the search firm Heidrick & Struggles) has a list of candidates," Anderson said, adding Apple had decided Thompson should not pursue the candidates until Wednesday's announcements. "I know expect John Thompson to be aggressively pursuing these candidates. I'd hope that within the next three months, we'd have a new CEO."
